title: Fragment

thumbnail.alt_text: A work made of cotton and wool (camelid), plain weave with discontinuous wefts and single dovetailed tapestry weave; edged with cross-knit loop stitches.

artist_display:
Moche-Huari
Possibly Huarmey Valley, north-central coast, Peru
medium_display: Cotton and wool (camelid), plain weave with discontinuous wefts and single dovetailed tapestry weave; edged with cross-knit loop stitches
publication_history: Walter Lehmann with Heinrich Doering, Kunstgeschichete des Altan Peru (Berlin: Verlag Ernst Wasmuth A.G., 1924), pl. 119. Walter Lehmann, The Art of Old Peru (Ernst Wasmuth, 1924), 64, fig. 119. Allen Wardwell, Art Institute of Chicago, Primitive Art in the Collections of the Art Institute of Chicago (Art Institute of Chicago, 1965), fig. 26. Else Regensteiner, Geometric Design in Weaving (Schiffer Publishing, 1986), 43, fig. 3-9. Richard Townsend with Elizabeth Pope, Indian Art of the Americas at the Art Institute of Chicago (Chicago: Art Institute of Chicago with Yale University Press, 2016), 324, cat. 290.
exhibition_history:
Art Gallery of the University of Notre Dame, The Art of Ancient Peru, December 20, 1961-January 28, 1962

The School of the Art Institute Museum Seminary Exhibition, God, Man and Beast: Metamorphosis in Native American Art, May 9- June 6, 1979

The Art Institute of Chicago, Africa, Oceania and the Americas, December 18, 1985- March 17, 1986

The Art Institute of Chicago, Africa, Oceania and the Americas, January 17 - June 17, 1991

Art Institute of Chicago, Elizabeth F. Cheney and Agnes Allerton Textile Galleries, Mexican, Central, and South American Textiles: A Living Legacy, Oct. 28, 1992-Jan. 17, 1993.

The Art Institute of Chicago, Africa, Oceania and the Americas, October 27, 1994- March 8, 1995

The Art Institute of Chicago, Africa, Oceania and the Americas, January 29- March 23, 1998

The Art Institute of Chicago, Africa, Oceania and the Americas, December 9, 2004- April 14, 2005
provenance_text: Eduard Gaffron (1861–1931), Lima, Peru, from 1892 to 1912, then Berlin, from 1912 [History of the Department report (Joanne Behrens, 1985) and correspondence in curatorial file]; by descent to his children Mercedes Gaffron, Berlin then Durham, SC, and Hans Gaffron (1902–1979), Berlin then Chicago [correspondence and documentation of the Gaffron Collection in curatorial file]; sold to the Art Institute, 1955.
